variant.question: Mark the statement most reasonable regarding a valley inversion.

options.text: Over night, cool dense air as a result of radiation cooling will descend along the mountain slopes into the basin and lead to the development of a valley inversion.
Small scale density variations due to turbulent mixing (mainly caused by the roughness of rocks) are a significant prerequisite for the formation of valley inversions.
If the incident solar radiation is non-uniform because of orographic conditions, the development of a valley inversion is very likely during daytime.
Provided that the lee side winds are able to displace the air at the bottom of the basin, the Foehn effect is the predominant factor in the development of a valley inversion.

variant.question: A valley has filled with relatively cold air during the night, topped by an inversion. On the next day, a warm air mass is advected into the area of the valley at upper levels. Which development has to be expected with the next few hours?

options.text: The inversion will become stronger
A dry adiabatic temperature gradient will replace the inversion.
The inversion will weaken
The warm air will replace the cold air in the valley, the inversion will dissolve.

variant.question: When in the upper part of a layer warm air is advected the:

options.text: stability increases in the layer.
wind will back with increasing height in the northern hemisphere.
stability decreases in the layer.
wind speed will always decrease with increasing height in the northern hemisphere.

variant.question: What may happen in a valley inversion?

options.text: Windshear of 30 to 50 kt.
It is the starting point of the lenticularis clouds formation.
Light wind with a high-temperature gradient.
Heavy rain.

variant.question: In a valley an inversion can be formed by..

options.text: katabatic winds with cold air.
turbulent air due to rotors.
advection of moist air from the sea.
heat from the sun in the afternoon.

variant.question: What should be expected during an approach to a runway located in a valley, if a surface-based temperature inversion is reported?

options.text: Visibility reduction.
Temperature increase throughout the descent.
Strong convective turbulences.
Anabatic winds.

variant.question: Which of the following is the most significant meteorological hazard to be considered when descending into an airport where a valley inversion exists?

options.text: Poor visibility
Turbulence
Rain
Microburst

variant.question: A well-developed inversion exists in a valley. Which of the following describes a flight hazard and may influence the performance of an aircraft departing from an airfield on the floor of the valley?

options.text: Strong winds above the inversion layer of up to 30 knots to 50 knots.
Anabatic winds blowing downhill due to the temperature inversion.
Air flow in a vertical direction along the upwind side of the valley.
Orographic uplift in the afternoon forming cumuliform clouds above the inversion with associated vertical wind shear.

options.text: Strong winds above the inversion layer of up to 30 kts to 50 kts.
Air flow in a vertical direction along the upwind side of the valley.
Anabatic winds blowing downhill due to temperature inversion.
